Award.AwardTitle: The Effect of Stellar Magnetic Eruptions on Stars and Their Environments
Award.AbstractNarration:
M dwarf stars (which are cooler and less massive than the Sun, but are the most common stars in the universe) are thought to be the most likely to harbor planetary systems. The potential habitability of these planets is likely to depend on the magnetic activity of their host star. Habitable planets are likely to lie close to their host star, and M dwarf stars flare more frequently and more energetically than the Sun. The space weather associated with these flares might be the deciding factor that determines whether these planets can harbor life. Planetary habitability is a subject of broad interest among the general public, and it crosses many scientific disciplines. The detection of space weather among other stars would open the door to studies that could advance our understanding of space weather in our solar system as well as the origins of life on Earth. This project will involve the training of a graduate student, who will not only learn radio observing techniques but will also learn how to coordinate international observing campaigns. The PI is the US representative commissioning a new facility in The Netherlands (LOFAR) for low-frequency radio observations.

The PI and her graduate student will use the JVLA and the LOFAR radio telescopes to observe flares from a small sample of nearby M dwarf stars. They will also arrange for simultaneous observations at other wavelengths. Their primary goal is to detect and characterize events analogous to solar coronal mass ejections, which have never been observed in other stellar systems. The PI has an excellent track record conducting multiwavelength observations of stellar flares, with a particular specialty in radio observations. By analogy with space weather in our solar system, it is the radio observations that hold the most potential for detecting CME?s from other stars.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was motivated by the need to understand better the environments that stars create that could either be helpful or harmful to life. Space weather on our Sun takes the form of flares, coronal mass ejections, and accelerated particles. Flares on stars can be studied easily, but coronal mass ejections are more important to space weather, which can potentially be incompatible with life on an exoplanet if taken to an extreme. This project used new and upgraded facilities in the Netherlands and New Mexico to to look for a specific observational signature that originates from the CME. Part of the project involved using solar observations of CMEs and flares to establish the validity of the approach of extracting information on velocity, mass and kinetic energy from analysis of stellar dynamic spectra and through the use of scaling laws between CME and flare properties. We performed the first robust search for CMEs in nearby stars using radio dynamics spectra at low frequencies. We established criteria for selecting target stars: they needed to be nearby, for sensitivity reasons, have a high flaring rate to probe a close association with CMEs, have constraints on coronal temperatures and densities to put constrains on coronal scale height, and photospheric magnetic field measurements to examine extrapolations into the corona, and finally previous evidence of radio bursts. We performed 64 hours of observations of one pair of stars, and 20 hours on another. No type II bursts were observed during this time.  We would have expected 1.2 flares per hour above a flare energy where all solar flares have an associated CME, and 1 flare every 27 hours using a large-scale model coronal to estimate which flares were capable to driving an observable shock. We examined astrophysical origins for the lack of detections, starting with a mismatch between observing sensitivity and type II paramseters, where the the CME speed can exceed the Alfevn speed, and whether flares occur in the absence of CMEs. This was the first robust observational constraint on the absence of stellar coronal mass ejections, and the implications run counter to the usually assumed scenario of scaling solar activity up by orders of magnitude to fit the stellar case.

The intellectual merit of the project lies in the convergence of ideas from two separate fields and application to a third. Recent advances in understanding how solar flares, coronal mass ejections, and energetic particles are related to each other has resulted in development of the concept of a ?solar eruptive event? which encompasses all three. The exoplanet community has been investigating aspects of stellar activity related to habitability, and finding that all three aspects of eruptive events ? flares, coronal mass ejections, and energetic particles ? are important to a comprehensive investigation of the effects of magnetic eruptions on exoplanet companions. Recent results from exoplanet studies show that planets around M dwarfs are exceedingly common, which together with the commonality of M dwarfs in our galaxy make this the dominant mode of star and planet configurations. The closeness of the exoplanets to the parent M star motivate a comprehensive understanding of habitability for these systems. Combining these two lines of research results in increased understanding of the magnetic effects on stars as well as the effect on exoplanet host stars.


The project made connections between stars and planets, and brought together several usually separate fields ? solar physics, stellar astronomy and exoplanet studies ? which have previously had only loose connections. Stellar astronomy typically uses the Sun as a model for understanding magnetic activity effects, and exoplanet studies use scalings from the Sun coupled with scalings from large samples of stars. The project promoted the training of a graduate student in an exciting emerging field and provided career development opportunities for the graduate student, who successfully defended this, his dissertation project. The project broadened the participation of an underrepresented group ? the PI is a female, now-tenured astronomer. The project enhanced partnerships, both between JHU and STScI, as well as internationally (the PI is the lone U.S. participant in the LOFAR Transients Key Project Council). The results were disseminated broadly, via publication in refereed journals, and public talks.
